LV.note: (2021) - Trips to China is the most common way Latvians get recruited to work for Chinese intelligence services.“These “tourists” are most likely to be members of a specific profession – journalists, politicians and scientists. In order to maintain secrecy, Beijing may offer the trip to China not to the person it is interested in, but instead to one of their relatives, be it their spouse, children or parents. Upon returning to their home country, the Chinese embassy asks the “tourists” to repay the generous trip with loyalty. Initially, it may be a simple social media entry that portrays China in a positive light. Then, perhaps an interview with a local media outlet to talk about the prosperity witnessed in China. In special cases, you may have to repay the favor by betraying your country.  https://www.eureporter.co/world/latvia/2021/03/25/its-about-time-we-started-discussing-chinas-influence-in-latvia/

ZA.note:
While the current evidence points to trips from two universities (North West University and Stellenbosch University), which justifies a "Few" rating, it‘s worth noting the historical context. In 2019, a larger delegation of twelve senior faculty members from 12 South African universities explored relationships with Chinese universities. This past activity, while outside the current timeframe, suggests a broader pattern of engagement that may continue to influence current academic relationships. The involvement of multiple institutions and the potential for ongoing collaborations makes these trips significant, even if the current evidence shows a smaller scale than in the past.

It is considered as signficant as the PRC and PRC conencted identities continue offering multiple scholarships to Myanmar students to study in China and PRC is the only country which provides scholarship for Myanmar students with stipend to continue studying in their respective home countries.
MM.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

UG.evidence: PRC has offered scholarships to Ugandan scholars especially at Makerere University. On 26th July 2022, it was reported on Makerere Website that 24 scholarships had been offered by the Chinese embassy.
UG.note: There's evidence of such trips, but not in the period under research.
UG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Agather Atuhaire

MZ.evidence: While there is no evidence of this having happened in the period covered by the 2023 Index, there's evidence of these trips having occurred in the past.
MZ.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Sérgio Chichava

AO.evidence: Visits by Angolan scholars to China have occurred in the past, but no evidence was found for the current period. During this period, there have been numerous visits by Chinese universities and scholars to Angola to promote China-Angola cooperation in academia.
AO.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

JP.evidence: No such case has been reported.
JP.answerer: Answered by Maiko Ichihara, and has been reviewed by Ryohei Suzuki and Yuki Moritarni

ID.evidence:
China has attracted Indonesian students to study in their country through scholarships. As of 2019 there are 15,780 Indonesian students currently studying in China.

China also has a scholarship program that specifically targets the largest Islamic organization in Indonesia, namely Nahdlatul Ulama (NU). Students who are affiliated with NU get a special quota to continue their tertiary education in China for free. This scholarship is called the Santri scholarship. They are often invited to attend events organized by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) such as the Xinjiang Brief Forum.
ID.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

KR.evidence:
I recently had the opportunity to travel around Beijing and Sichuan province at the invitation of the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. I was accompanied by several domestic power bloggers who are active in cyberspace. We were part of a programme called Public Diplomacy. Public diplomacy is a form of modern diplomacy that seeks to win the hearts and minds of other countries through charm and communication.


Yoo Sang-cheol
Head of China Research, JoongAng Ilbo
KR.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

KH.evidence: Yes, this regular all-expenses paid trips to China are common among Cambodian scholars.

US.evidence: The Wire China reported that there are at least 40 different U.S.-China track-two groups between US and Chinese scholars and some of these groups meet in person in China. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "More than a few" rating. Some track-two groups can impact government policy. Therefore, this Indiciator deserves a "Significant" rating.
US.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

DE.evidence: There are more than a few scholars that have been invited to a conference or other meetings in China and often the trip would be financed by the PRC-connected institution. However, research trips are more often self-financed by the scholar, as illustrated by a recent example of two German Sinologists traveling to Xinjiang.
DE.answerer: Answered by Angela Stanzel, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

GB.evidence: There is no public evidence of the indicator phenomenon. However, given the close links between the academic realms in the two countries, it is likely that regular trips take place both ways.
GB.answerer: Answered by Leo Shaw, and has been reviewed by Sam Dunning and Andrew Yeh

AU.evidence:
Australian citizen Maureen A Huebel was welcomed by the Institute for Communication and Borderland Governance of Guangzhou-based Jinan University and the Institute of China's Borderland Studies at Zhejiang Normal University during her visit in 2023. Although she describes herself as an academic, she has no formal affiliation with a university, and so her case is insignificant.

While there is little publicly available evidence further supporting this statement, given the close research partnerships Chinese and Australian universities have, it is likely that more scholars have taken trips to the PRC that are organised by PRC-connected entities.
AU.answerer: Answered by Leo Shaw, and has been reviewed by Kevin Mooney and Andrew Yeh

IL.evidence: The University of International Business and Economics (UIBE) has opened a local branch in Israel. The students and staff go to China for a summer semester, funded by UIBE, which is partly funded by the PRC.
IL.answerer: Answered by The Institute for National Security Studies (INSS), and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
